paper.title: Social cognitive theory and individual reactions to computing technology: a longitudinal study
paper.publisher: Society for Information Management and The Management Information Systems Research Center
paper.abstract: A model, based on Bandurau0027s Social Cognitive Theory, was developed to test the influence of computer self-efficacy, outcome expectations, affect, and anxiety on computer usage. The model was tested using longitudinal data gathered from 394 end users over a one-year interval. Significant relationships were found between computer self-efficacy and outcome expectations, and between self-efficacy and affect and anxiety and use. Performance outcomes were found to influence affect and use, while affect was significantly related to use. Overall, the findings provide strong confirmation that both self-efficacy and outcome expectations impact on an individualu0027s affective and behavioral reactions to information technology.
